ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how various histories of citizenship and public health intentionally coincide with processes of racialization in ways that mediate interactions that guide the creation and perpetuation of various societal structures.

I learned how to critically analyze primary and secondary historical documents and gained a deeper understanding of how citizenship and race have influenced and shaped public health throughout history.
I was able to engage with historical analysis in a way I havent been able to before. The class environment was amazing so I have also left with tons of insight from the perspectives of my peers.

This course was fantastic for gaining insight on how to take-on a significant historical research project. Additionally, it was great for understanding and analyzing primary sources through a critical lens and also how to thoughtfully read and absorb secondary literature.

The course focused a lot on analyzing primary sources, which is useful preparation for higher level history courses and the senior essay. It also drew connections between meanings of "citizen" (e.g., immigrant status; second-class citizen), geographical boundaries created around perceived citizenship status (e.g., redlining, ethnic enclaves), and how public health officials created and enforced public health initiatives that had disparate outcomes along racial and ethnic lines.

The complicated interactions between public health, citizenship, and race (how public health has historically been a tool of oppression, but how it has also been leveraged as a tool of inclusion). Topics included quarantine, health activism, sanitation, colonialism, and more. Super thought-provoking and obviously very relevant given our pandemic, but also broadly relevant in this history of medicine.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: Professor Rich is an excellent facilitator of discussion and provides lots of space for students to voice their thoughts while offering very enriching comments of her own to supplement discussion. The readings were generally very interesting and provided for a lot of content to think through and discuss in class. Additionally, the structure of assignments was really helpful as each assignment throughout the semester was designed to build up to a final project, so it helped distribute workload over the semester.

not necessarily a weakness but some readings covered themes that were perhaps a bit too similar and sometimes felt repetitive; however, this speaks to the prevalence and robustness of these trends throughout history.

The course was presented very wonderfully. All the topics of each class flowed and really addressed the larger questions of the seminar. I think the structured format of each classicebreakers, presentation, discussion, primary source analysiswas perfect and classes never dragged. The assignments also built up and cumulated in the research project, which made me actually learn things and use them for the next assignment.

I looked forward to this class every week! I think Professor Rich really cultivated a space where we could have dynamic conversations. I felt like I was in community with Professor Rich and my classmates, and that we were all going on a very valuable learning journey together.
This was, by far, the best class I have taken at Yale. I was more engaged with this course than any other, and I felt encouraged to share my perspective during class time.
The current class structure (a mix of student presentations, discussions, and primary source analysis) is a great learning environment
Great course! Prof. Rich is incredible, and the content is interesting

Strengths: Despite the online format, this class was very enjoyable because a variety of formats were used to discuss the material (brainstorming board, student presentation, discussion questions, primary source exploration). Prof. Rich is an incredible professor with a vast amount of knowledge. Workload is very manageable. Weaknesses: Many of our discussions came back to the same points, so it would be interesting to incorporate broader academic perspectives into discussions.
Great discussions and readings, manageable assignments, and super kind professor! No real notes for improvement.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think Professor Rich was very understanding about some of the challenges that came with navigating classes during a pandemic, and she was always accommodating and available to help.
It was well executed and I love the introduction time each meeting.
Professor Rich showed that with an incredibly thoughtful professor, virtual seminars can still be a really safe, comfortable, and productive space.

Professor Rich was one of the few professors who understood the magnitude of COVID-19's impact on students. She was accessible and flexible when any personal issues arose. It was very apparent that she cared about students' wellbeing/mental health in addition to their engagement with the overall course themes/material.
Prof Rich was great about making COVID-19 accommodations/being flexible with students' needs

I really loved how we had a brief check-in question at the start of each class, and I actually enjoyed the break-out rooms we'd have to discuss primary sources. They really made me feel more involved with the course and my classmates.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes

Yes! Not only did I learn and analyze things very relevant because of COVID, but I feel like I've learned new tools to interpret history. There was a big focus on primary source analysis, which I thought was very important and useful.
Yes I would! If you are at all interested in public health and medicine I highly recommend this course.
Yes absolutely! Professor Rich was wonderful, the readings were fascinating, and the conversations were enlightening!

Definitely. This course provided so much great insight and history on the intersections of health with axes of citizenship, race, gender, and others. Whether you are interested in ERM, HSHM, health broadly, or race and citizenship broadly, there is so much critical content to learn from this class.

Yes, especially students who will pursue a career in medicine or public health, or students interested in the relationship/power dynamic between racial and ethnic minorities and medical/public health professionals
Yes!

Yes! This course covers a broad history for anyone interested in the topic, so you learn so much. There is also a very strong focus on primary source work, which is a very useful skill to have. Professor Rich is also an incredible professor that you should definitely take a class with.
Absolutely! Really well-taught, and the concepts themselves are also really important to think about (both in terms of public health and in terms of general reflections on race/citizenship).

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
